original_title: Only 31,000 out of 500,000 Sri Lankans pay income tax: parliament committee
original_body_lines: ECONOMYNEXT – Only 31,000 Sri Lankans of some 500,000 persons with registered income tax files pay personal income tax while 328 registered limited companies out of 105,000 contribute to 82 percent of tax revenue, an official said.

Chair of the parliamentary Sectoral Oversight Committee on National Economic and Physical Plans Mahindananda Aluthgamage had said at a meeting of the committee on July 06 that regular discussions will be held with Sri Lanka Customs, the Excise Department and the Inland Revenue Department (IRD) on providing facilities including a digital data system linking the three entities in a bid to increase state revenue.
The need to re-register private tax files had also been discussed.

A statement from parliament released on Wednesday July 12 quoting Aluthgamage said it was important to maintain inflation, reserves and state revenue in an “optimal condition” by December by the time of the second review of the International Monetary Fund (IMF), given that the “said factors must be taken into account when granting loans”.

At the July 06 meeting, the chair of the oversight committee had highlighted what the statement called the failure of the IRD to collect tax revenue. The committee is making positive improvements in this regard, the statement said.

Some 904 billion rupees in arrears due to the IRD was also discussed at the committee meeting as well as discussions said to be underway with Minister of Justice Wijeyadasa Rajapaksa on amending the Inland Revenue Act, while MP Aluthgamage had assured his assistance in filling existing vacancies at the IRD.

According to the statement, the Inland Revenue Commissioner General had told the committee that the tax revenue target given by the government for the year 2023 of 1.6 trillion rupees was expected to be earned by 40 percent in the first six months and 60 percent in the remaining six months. The target for the first six months has already been met and work is underway to generate expected tax revenue in the remaining six months, he had said.

The need to establish a systematic mechanism to regulate the collection of tax revenue was highlighted at the meeting, the statement said, with committee members as well as officials pointing out that problems in tax collection had cropped up due to inaccuracies in data provided for the registration of companies.

Members of the Committee Wimalaweera Dissanayake, Eran Wickramaratne, Sudath Manjula, Gunathilaka Rajapaksha, Dhammika Perera, Udayana Kirindigoda, Karunadasa Kodithuwakku, Madhura Withanage, and Mohomad Muzammil had attended the meeting, along with a a group of officials that included the Inland Revenue Commissioner General.

Sri Lanka has been compelled to increase its tax revenue in the wake of the 2022 currency crisis, the worst in decades, and the subsequent agreement with the IMF over a 2.9 billion dollar extended fund facility. However, resistance to a hike in progressive personal income tax has been high, with many high-income earning professionals in the state sector holding a number of protests against the increase.

Value added taxes were also raised to 15 percent from 8 percent last year. Another 2.5 percent cascading tax was imposed on top of VAT, the effect of which was estimated to be around 4.5 or more through the cascading effect.
The IMF had reportedly asked the cash strapped Sri Lankan government to impose taxes on all who receive monthly income of above 41,667 rupees as a prior condition for the bailout, but
President Ranil Wickremesinghe’s administration had instead imposed a Pay As You Earn (PAYE) tax on everyone who earns over 100,000 rupees a month.

The IMF has defended the tax hike, arguing that creditors and investors will not support Sri Lanka because tax to GDP had fallen steeply. Taxes, including value added taxes were slashed in 2019 December to target a ‘persistent output gap’, after serial currency crises from flexible inflation targeting reduced growth.

According to Commissioner General of Inland Revenue D R S Hapuarachchi, Sri Lanka has collected 11.93 billion rupees in advance personal income tax in March 2023, up from 3.1 billion rupees in January.
In the first quarter 24,577 billion rupees were collected from APIT. A comparison with last year was not given.
In January 3,106 million rupees was collected, in February 10,540 million rupees and 11,931 in March. (Colombo/Jul13/2023)
